results.title: Food handling
results.creator_credit: Kathleen O'Brien and New Zealand National Film Unit
results.brief_description: Contrasts the healthy interior of a clean restaurant with the conditions of a careless eating-house. Shows the use of mechanised handling of food and stainless steel containers for hygiene.

results.title: Food from the reluctant earth
results.creator_credit: Edwin Scragg, Lesley Hammond and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Examines the cereal belt area of South Australia, where farmers must grow crops without irrigation and maintain livestock with a minimum of water. Explains the wheat/legume rotation system that enables farmers to obtain high yields.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Edwin Scragg, Lesley Hammond and South Australian Film Corporation

results.title: Food for thought
results.creator_credit: R. Ronald Brown, Michel Laloride, Gerald Wilson, Christopher Tate and Century II Motion Pictures
results.brief_description: Television personality Blake Emmons presents the safe handling of food in the home, based on two principles - the time and temperature rule and the cross contamination rule.

results.title: Food for thought
results.creator_credit: T.A. Abraham, K Khandpur, Indian Film Unit and UNICEF
results.brief_description: This prize-winning film illustrates the problems of the rural community of Orissa as it strives to combat hunger and malnutrition by use of improved methods of poultry and fish farming, cultivation of school gardens and nutrition education.

results.title: Food for Sport (+Booklet)
results.brief_description: Karen Inge, a Melbourne based dietician and Peter Beukner, doctor to the Australian Swimming team, present eight golden rules for sound sports nutrition. Booklet available.

results.title: Food for fun
results.brief_description: Uses a story about a young fisherman to teach the basics of nutrition. Shows the five food groups as favourite foods of animals. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.brief_description: Pictures the human battle against hunger from the beginning of time. Includes scenes of starvation which are contrasted with views of affluence and waste. Suitable for secondary level.

results.title: Food and people
results.brief_description: Draws a contrast between people who have plenty to eat and those who have next to nothing. Followers of Thomas Malthus are convinced that a world of plenty will never be possible; others believe the world’s population should be limited; and another group advocates the increase of food production and distribution. The latter concept also stresses conservation of resources and improved agricultural methods. Emphasises that with free world trade, peoples of all nations will benefit. Suggests that a world of plenty provides greater chances for individual security and world peace.

The latter concept also stresses conservation of resources and improved agricultural methods. Emphasises that with free world trade, peoples of all nations will benefit. results.title: Food and growth
results.brief_description: Explains the functions of the mouth, stomach and intestine in the digestion of food. Shows how food is carried by the circulatory system to the cells, allowing cell division and growth. Suitable for upper primary and lower and middle secondary levels.

results.title: Food additives
results.creator_credit: Shane Mulcahy, Deborah Manners, Box Hill College of Technical and Further Education and Open Tafe
results.brief_description: A discussion with Dr. K. Farrer, author of “Fancy eating that” who describes the history of food additives and examines what is added and why. He also addresses the safety aspects of additives and regulations to control their use. Hosted by Peter Couchman.
